moves.2. Bg2 e6: I decided to play for the Nf6/e6/b6 structure which is, more or less, a generally reliable all-purpose formation. If 3. e4 then I figured I could reply with 3...d5 inviting a French structure with 4.e5 Nfd7 5.d4 c5 6.c3 Nc6 7.Nf3 Qb6 8.O-O Be7 or possibly 4.exd5 exd5 with a nicely active open position.
moves.3. a3: The a3/h3 moves are often criticised as time wasting, but a3 here is actually a very decent move to prevent the common Bb4 pin to the knight.
moves.3... d5: Grabbing my share of the center, blunting off his bishop, and allowing for the queenside fianchetto to oppose his king's bishop.
moves.4. d4 b6 5. Bg5: These pins can be intimidating, but the bark is often worse than the bite - Nd2 and the pin is neutralised and the bishop ready to be kicked. Perhaps Bf4 was stronger to guard e5.
moves.5... Nbd7 6. Nf3 Bd6: Bb4 was taken away, but d6 is a great square as well for the bishop - it, the two knights, and the pawns stake their claim on the center. It will combine nicely to aim at the kingside with the parallel Bb7.
moves.7. Nbd2 h6: By kicking first, I reserve the right to chase the bishop and castle queenside. 8.Bh4 g5, 8.Bf4 Bxf4, 8.Be3 and the e-pawn is blocked.
moves.8. Bxf6 Nxf6 9. e3: Likely a positonal mistake - White weakens the king's protection on the King's light squares. The e-pawn often hangs back with the kingside fianchetto
moves.9... O-O 10. Bf1: Another mistake I believe - white wastes some time redeploying his bishop. True it was blunted, but 9.O-O Bb7 and playing Ne5 or trying to get a break with c4 would have been more favourable for white.
moves.10... Bb7 11. Bd3 c5: Time to break with c5 and gain the c-file or possibly cramp with an advance to c4.
moves.12. b3 cxd4 13. exd4 Ne4: A great outpost for the knight to pressure white (also eyeing the weak c3). If Bxe4 then dxe4 and then 15... e3 to juggle up the kingside.
moves.14. Nb1: I believe white made the move to guard c3 from the knight.
moves.14... Rc8: Grabbing the semi-open file to bear down on the weak c2/c3 squares.
moves.15. Nfd2: A mistake - leaving the weak f2 square open!
moves.15... Qf6: Threatening mate with Qxf7, and freeing my finachetto'd bishop in an exchange.
moves.16. Nxe4: Bxe4 was stronger as the knight on d2 was guarding more critical squares.
moves.16... dxe4 17. Bc4 e3: Threats now abound in the king's quadrant - exf2, Bxh1...
moves.18. O-O Bf4: A trap is laid out - if 19.gxf4 Qg6+ 20.Qg4 Qxg4#, or if 19.fxe3 Bxe3+ 20.Rf2 Qxf2#
moves.19. c3 exf2+ 20. Kxf2 Bb8+ 21. Ke1 Qg5: An active retreat by the Queen.
moves.22. Ra2 e5: Blast open the center to line up the rooks on the exposed king.
moves.23. Be2: Leaves the bishop vulnerable to being pinned by a rook.
